newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Staid Zurich loosens up for big techno music fest.
newsitem.headline: Staid Zurich loosens up for big techno music fest.

text.p: Zurich, normally the staid centre of Swiss banking, traded suits and ties for wild and scanty costumes as up to half a million people descended on the city this weekend for its annual techno music "Street Parade".

Organisers on Sunday said between 400,000 and 500,000 people took part on Saturday in the parade -- focal point of Europe's second-biggest techno music fest after the "Love Parade" in Berlin, which drew up to a million dancers and spectators in July.
"I saw people who I thought would never go in costume to the street parade, people who normally wear suits and ties," organiser Christoph Soltmannowski told the weekly newspaper SonntagsBlick.
Techno fans, popularly known as ravers, poured in from around Europe to don their bizarre costumes, many of which were suitably scaled down for the summer heat.
Some participants wore only bright body paint and tangas while others danced to the booming sounds in leather harnesses, spiky collars and feather boas.
The five-hour parade along five km (three miles) of the city's lakefront featured 30 sound trucks with huge speakers and crowds of dancers.
Techno music is a mix of thundering beats and repetitive electronic bleeps supplied by disc jockeys equipped with massive sound systems.
"It all went peacefully," said a police spokesman in Zurich, Switzerland's biggest city with about one million inhabitants in the wider metropolitan area.
After the parade, ravers could choose among 30 all-night techno parties in sites ranging from the main train station to a forest clearing above the city.
Zurich's Street Parade started in 1992, three years after Berlin's Love Parade, and has grown from around 2,000 dedicated ravers the first time to 300,000 last year.

The Zurich festival under the motto "Love, peace and tolerance" is also a financial wellspring, generating sales estimated at around 50 million francs ($33 million) for everything from music CDs to railroad tickets. ($ = 1.507 Swiss Francs)
